description: From Middle English meynprise, maynprise, from Anglo-Norman mainprise.

entries.meaning: (law, historical) A writ directed to the sheriff, commanding him to take sureties, called mainpernors, for the prisoner's appearance, and to let him go at large.
(law, historical) Deliverance of a prisoner on security for his appearance at a day.

verbs.description: mainprise (third-person singular simple present mainprises, present participle mainprising, simple past and past participle mainprised)

entries.meaning: (transitive, law) To allow (a prisoner) to go at large, on his finding sureties, or mainpernors, for his appearance on a given day.
